soil_mix: Miracle-Gro Potting Mix, Nursery Potting Mix
origin_history: Transplanted from 25 oz. white pot into larger pot with fresh potting mix.
Brought indoors for one cold night for protection.
whats_been_logged: The plant is actively producing new blossoms and berries, with multiple clusters forming and ripening at the same time. Several young berries close to the crown show natural developmental irregularities while most fruit continues to size and color normally. Mulch now supports developing berries and helps maintain stable soil structure and moisture.
current_state: The plant is in vigorous fruiting condition with dense, healthy foliage and numerous berries at different stages of development. The crown remains clean and well-ventilated, and the recently added mulch supports developing fruit while keeping soil conditions cool and balanced. Overall growth is strong, productive, and visually stable.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows vigorous fruiting activity with a dense, healthy canopy and multiple berries at various stages of development. Leaf color remains deep green and glossy with no signs of wilt or stress. Newly added potting mix and soil fluffing improved aeration, and the mulch ring is properly placed away from the crown while providing support for developing berries. Several young berries appear bent, withered, or oddly formed, which is consistent with natural developmental variation, minor pollination miss, or early structural bruising near the crown. These berries are still firm and not decaying. Moisture reads low at the surface due to fresh soil incorporation, but the plant displays no signs of dehydration.
journal.actions: Avoid watering right now as expected rainfall will correct the low moisture reading. Do not fertilize today given the very low EC and salt levels that indicate balanced soil. Leave malformed young berries in place and do not attempt to reposition or prune them. Maintain the mulch ring exactly as it is to support developing fruit and reduce soil contact without touching the crown.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after the rain to ensure values rise into the ideal 35–55 range. Monitor berry ripening and allow malformed fruit to remain unless they become mushy or brown. Watch for additional blossoms as the plant is entering a high-production phase. Continue ensuring good airflow around the crown and avoid placing mulch or debris near it.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows vigorous, healthy growth with dense foliage, bright red blossoms, and multiple berries progressing evenly through mid-ripening. Leaf color is deep green and glossy with no signs of wilt or stress. The added mulch is positioned correctly, lifting berries from direct soil contact and helping regulate temperature. A few small cosmetic holes in the leaves appear stable and non-progressive. The pH reading of 11.13 is invalid due to a brief probe-contact failure, while all other metrics indicate stable, healthy soil conditions.
journal.actions: Take no watering action as moisture is ideal. Do not fertilize today, as EC and salt levels are balanced for active fruiting. Leave mulch placement as-is to protect developing berries and maintain soil cooling. Allow expected rainfall to handle hydration naturally.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture again tomorrow morning to ensure values remain between 40–55. Monitor berry ripening for even color progression. If future pH readings consistently fall below 5.2 or show additional contact failures, consider a small application of dolomite lime later in the week, but not today.

photos.caption: Low-angle view showing bright blossoms and ripening berries along the pot edge.
Side perspective highlighting evenly developing berries and dense foliage.
Wide shot capturing the whole plant with multiple berries at various ripening stages.
Front-facing view showing strong leaf mass and a healthy red blossom.
Plant viewed from above, showing balanced foliage and berry placement around the crown.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8:00 AM, otherwise sunny with a high near 86°F. Calm wind becoming south 5 to 8 mph in the morning. Partly cloudy tonight with a low around 66°F and southwest wind around 5 mph becoming calm in the evening.
journal.observations: The plant displays vigorous growth with multiple berries actively reddening and developing, though some show slight uneven coloring, mild misshaping, and raised achenes typical of heat stress combined with minor pollination inconsistency. The canopy remains full and healthy with strong leaf mass supporting active fruiting. Several leaves show tan lesions with crisp edges from old chewing or mechanical damage, plus a few white or gray pinpoint spots indicating possible early leaf spot, though no spreading, necrotic halos, or water-soaking patterns are visible. Soil temperature reached extremely high 105.8°F in the black pot under direct Florida sun. Moisture at 56 mS/cm indicates healthy hydration following earlier watering when soil was very dry.
journal.actions: Check moisture again at 3:00–4:00 PM and water lightly if reading drops below 30 mS/cm, otherwise skip watering until morning if it stays above 35–40 mS/cm. Place two thin handfuls of wood chips or light mulch around the pot edges only, not touching the crown, to reduce root zone heat by up to 15°F. Do not fertilize today; fertility at 16% is moderate-high and pH has dropped to 5.17, with feeding risking further pH decline. Continue neem spray on a 7-day cycle following yesterday's application. Do not prune healthy leaves as strawberries need strong leaf mass during fruiting.
journal.next_steps: Monitor pH closely over the next several days as it trends below ideal strawberry range at 5.17; apply a tiny pinch of dolomite lime if pH stays below 5.2 to stabilize acidity. Plan next fertilizer application in 5–7 days only if pH rises back above 5.4. Continue monitoring fruit development as berries progress through color change stage despite mild heat-related misshaping. Watch leaf spots for any spreading patterns though current damage appears to be low-level stress, sun flick, and occasional insect nibbles rather than active disease outbreak. Maintain mulch layer to protect root zone from extreme afternoon heat.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Asked whether watering was needed given probe readings and weather; advised to recheck moisture at 3:00–4:00 PM and water only if reading drops below 30 mS/cm, otherwise wait until morning. Asked about visible leaf spots; confirmed spots appear to be minor chewing, sunscald, mechanical rubbing, and a couple early fungal flecks but not yet active disease outbreak, with yesterday's neem spray providing good timing to interrupt both pest and early fungal activity.

Crown close-up displaying multiple berries at different color stages with open red bloom above.

Full view highlighting multiple red blooms with ripening and green berries visible throughout plant.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high near 86°F and a low around 65°F. Light southeast wind becoming south 5 to 9 mph in the morning. Partly cloudy overnight with south wind around 5 mph becoming calm in the evening.
journal.observations: The plant displays vigorously growing canopy with dense leaf coverage that is normal for a healthy strawberry but beginning to reach the stage where gentle pruning of damaged or diseased leaves will improve airflow. Multiple berries are developing with some showing mild misshapen appearance typical of incomplete pollination in early fruiting, which is extremely common outdoors and does not indicate health problems. One berry shows visible reddening beginning the color change stage. The canopy is lush but not excessive, with good overall structure and upright posture. Crown remains clean with active new leaf production. Minor chewing damage continues on some leaves but is not spreading rapidly. Soil appears dark and well-saturated following yesterday's watering with moisture at maximum reading of 100 mS/cm.
journal.actions: Do not fertilize today despite extremely low fertility earlier in the week; EC at 0.26 and salt at 130 mg/L indicate nutrients are accumulating in the soil and adding fertilizer now risks nutrient burn, leaf-edge browning, further fruit deformities, and reduced water uptake. Begin gentle selective pruning by removing only leaves that are yellowing, damaged, diseased, or folded downward blocking fruit clusters to maintain airflow without robbing plant energy. Do not remove healthy green leaves. Allow soil to rest and stabilize following heavy watering. Continue monitoring pest activity following neem application.
journal.next_steps: Wait to fertilize until EC drops below 0.15 mS/cm AND salt drops below 70 mg/L AND fertility drops below 8%, at which point soil will be depleted enough to benefit from feeding. Use Purived 4-5-5 for regular light feedings or Gardenwise 10-10-10 Plus at 1/4 strength only for container strawberries when fertilization timing is appropriate. Monitor berry ripening progression as color change accelerates on the reddening fruit. Check moisture within 24–48 hours as current 100 mS/cm reading indicates very high saturation. Continue observing for new chewing damage or pest activity following neem treatment. Remove any leaves showing new disease spots or significant damage to maintain airflow.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Asked whether there are too many leaves on top; confirmed the dense canopy is normal for vigorous growth but the plant is entering the stage where gentle pruning of only damaged, diseased, yellowing, or downward-folded leaves will improve airflow and fruit exposure without removing healthy productive foliage. Asked whether misshapen strawberries are acceptable; confirmed mild deformities are normal for early fruiting and typically result from incomplete pollination which is extremely common outdoors, with berries still ripening and tasting fine. Asked whether to fertilize now; advised against fertilization due to rising EC at 0.26 and salt at 130 mg/L indicating nutrient accumulation, with fertilization deferred until EC drops below 0.15, salt below 70, and fertility below 8%.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny and breezy with a high of 84°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant displays healthy active growth with developing berries progressing normally and new crowns forming. Leaf margins show minor chewing and several punctures consistent with leaf-feeding beetles, grasshoppers, or similar insects rather than aphid damage. One lower leaf displayed a dark spot resembling a fungal lesion, likely leaf spot or minor anthracnose, with no widespread infection visible on other foliage. Developing berries appear healthy with one berry showing old aphid residue but no active colonies visible. Soil moisture was completely dry at 2:00 PM in the Florida sun, requiring watering before readings could be taken. Moisture reading of 80 mS/cm reflects good hydration restoration approximately 2 hours after watering. Soil appears uniformly moist with no signs of rot or fungus.
journal.actions: Remove the lower leaf with the dark fungal-looking spot by cutting at the stem rather than through the blade to prevent spread and avoid damaging nearby new growth. Use clean scissors or shears. Apply Captain Jack's Neem Oil at 4:39 PM with perfect timing to address residual pest pressure and reduce minor chewing from beetles. Water when bone dry as done today; moisture restored successfully. Do not reapply neem for 7 days to avoid leaf burn in strong sun. No fertilizer required today; EC and fertility are improving and growth continues normally.
journal.next_steps: Monitor for new chewing damage on newer leaves over the next 48 hours. Apply Captain Jack's DeadBug (Spinosad) in late afternoon every 5–7 days if new holes appear on fresh foliage. Check moisture around 1:00–2:00 PM tomorrow and water if reading drops below 30 mS/cm given the plant's fast-drying tendency in full Florida sun. When berries start blushing, consider providing shade from direct overhead sun between 1:00–3:00 PM and create airflow under the plant to reduce fungal risk. Continue monitoring for any new dark spots or spreading fungal patterns on remaining foliage.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Asked whether the leaf with the dark spot could be cut off; confirmed removal is appropriate and the leaf should be cut at its stem rather than through the blade to avoid damaging nearby new growth. The spot appeared isolated and resembled fungal lesion rather than insect damage, making removal the correct preventive action.
follow_up: [4:39 PM] Applied Captain Jack's Neem Oil to address pest pressure and reduce chewing damage. Cut the spotted lower leaf at the stem using clean shears.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 62°F overnight. Wind gusts up to 19 mph with bright conditions throughout the day.
journal.observations: The plant displays strong compact vegetative growth with a dense healthy canopy showing upright posture and steady fruit development. Multiple berries are entering the green enlargement stage indicating successful pollination and adequate nutrient uptake. Close-up photos reveal green aphids clustered on developing berry surfaces, especially around the seeds. Localized chewing damage is visible on some leaves consistent with leaf beetles, grasshoppers, caterpillars, or weevils, though this damage is minor compared to the aphid presence. Crown and stems appear clear with no fungal spotting. Soil moisture at 9.00 mS/cm is the driest reading ever logged for this plant, approaching stress dehydration levels that could slow berry ripening, stall young leaf development, and increase risk of blossom and fruit drop.
journal.actions: Water immediately with 3/4 to 1 cup poured slowly and evenly around the pot, avoiding the crown directly. Apply Captain Jack's Neem Oil between 4:00 PM and 6:00 PM to treat aphids on fruit and foliage, spraying top and undersides of leaves, crown area, and fruit clusters with light even coverage. Do not drench the plant. Repeat neem application every 4–5 days for 2 more cycles. Do not fertilize today despite extremely low fertility at 2.0%; aphids thrive on nitrogen spikes and treatment must occur first. No lime required; pH at 5.86 is on the lower edge but acceptable and not dangerous. Do not mix multiple spray products together.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture either later today or tomorrow morning to confirm hydration recovery following watering. Monitor undersides of leaves tomorrow morning for aphid activity and assess treatment effectiveness over the next 48 hours. Plan to apply Purived 4-5-5 at 1/4 strength on December 5 or 6 if aphid population reduces significantly. Continue watching for additional chewing damage patterns though current damage is minor. Monitor berry development for any deformities or spreading issues related to aphid feeding.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Asked whether visible marks in close-up photos were chew marks on leaves; confirmed the damage pattern shows localized chewing consistent with leaf beetles, grasshoppers, caterpillars, or occasionally weevils rather than disease or scorch. Crown and stems remain clear with no fungal spotting visible.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight. Wind gusts up to 19 mph with no midday rain expected.
journal.observations: The plant displays strong growth with a dense healthy canopy showing upright posture and active fruit development. Multiple berries are entering the green enlargement stage indicating successful pollination and adequate nutrient uptake. Close-up photos reveal localized chewing damage on leaves consistent with leaf beetles, grasshoppers, caterpillars, or occasionally weevils, with no signs of fungal spotting. Crown and stems appear clear and healthy. One photo shows very small green insects clustered on a berry identified as aphids in early stages before significant spread. Warm windy conditions are increasing both transpiration demand and insect activity.
journal.actions: Apply Captain Jack's DeadBug (Spinosad) late afternoon or just before sunset to address chewing insects including caterpillars, beetles, and thrips while remaining bee-safe when dry with active blossoms present. Treat aphids using the same DeadBug application as it controls both chewing insects and aphids effectively without requiring multiple spray products. Water lightly with 1/3 to 1/2 cup today; moisture at 54 mS/cm is not yet dry but warm windy conditions accelerate water loss. Do not mix multiple spray products together. No fertilizer required today despite very low EC; plant shows no deficiency symptoms and will be reassessed in 2-3 days. No lime needed; pH is in perfect range.
journal.next_steps: Apply DeadBug spray after 5:00 PM when bee activity decreases to protect pollinators. Monitor chewing damage and aphid population over next 48 hours to assess treatment effectiveness. Recheck moisture within 24 hours given warm windy conditions accelerating transpiration. Consider Purived 4-5-5 application in 2-3 days if fertility continues declining without visible plant stress. Watch for any new insect activity or damage patterns on developing berries and foliage.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Asked whether marks visible in close-up photos were chew marks on leaves; confirmed the damage pattern is localized chewing consistent with leaf beetles, grasshoppers, caterpillars, or occasionally weevils rather than disease or scorch. Crown and stems remain clear with no fungal spotting visible.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 68°F overnight. Partly cloudy around 11:00 AM returning to bright sun at 1:00 PM. Wind gusts up to 20 mph.
journal.observations: The plant displays excellent health with deep green glossy upright foliage showing no chlorosis, burn, or wilt. Multiple strong red blooms are visible with several berries in early swell phase showing proper size and seed spacing. Crowns remain clean and fully exposed. Soil appears even, loose, and well-topped with uniform moisture distribution and no pooling or anaerobic patches. Plant structure is compact and balanced with no legginess. Runner nodes are forming but have not extended yet. Slight edge nibbling on one leaf indicates harmless cosmetic insect activity with no visible infestation.
journal.actions: Do not water today or tomorrow; soil moisture is high and overnight temperature drop increases overwatering risk. No fertilizer required; EC is in optimal zone and adding more could spike salts. Optionally perform light canopy cleaning by gently shaking away wind-blown debris without pruning. Check soil firmness tomorrow to ensure stability after high moisture and wind gusting, gently pressing to confirm firmness while keeping soil loose around crown. No pest sprays needed while flowers are open.
journal.next_steps: Monitor for runner initiation as vigorous growth suggests runners will begin extending soon. Watch for berry color shift as temperatures warm during midday sun exposure. Continue observing fruit development as berries progress through early swell phase. Recheck moisture levels in 24–48 hours before considering next watering. Monitor crown exposure as soil settles to ensure it remains above soil line.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 66°F overnight. Wind gusts up to 15 mph.
journal.observations: The plant displays deep green upright turgid leaves indicating excellent hydration and nutrient balance. Multiple red blossoms are now open with several berries forming and gaining size and texture. No signs of fungal spotting, wilt, or nutrient deficiency visible on any foliage. Soil surface appears well-leveled without gaps following the practice of filling probe holes after each reading. The pH dropped sharply from yesterday's 6.17 to 4.86, likely due to recent rain events, fresh acidic soil added to probe holes, and significant watering combined with cloud cover slowing evaporation. EC and salt levels rose moderately from watering dissolving nutrients in the fully saturated soil profile.
journal.actions: Do not add lime or pH amendments today despite low pH reading of 4.86; soil is fully saturated from morning watering and adjusting pH in saturated soil risks overshooting. Plan pH correction for tomorrow or next dry morning if pH remains below 5.2 using ½ tsp garden lime mixed into 1 cup water applied around outer pot ring away from crown. No watering needed today; moisture at 60 mS/cm combined with morning watering and wind will maintain adequate hydration until tomorrow morning. Continue filling probe holes with loose potting mix after each reading. No fertilizer required; fertility is rising naturally.
journal.next_steps: Correct pH tomorrow or next dry morning if readings remain below 5.2 to prevent restricted calcium and magnesium uptake affecting berry formation. Monitor moisture levels with increased wind gusts potentially accelerating drying above 20 mph. Check again late afternoon if wind speed increases significantly. Continue current soil addition practice to prevent pocket formation. Watch for berry color changes and continued fruit development as plant progresses through early fruit swell stage.
follow_up: [9:40 AM] Watered the plant in the morning; readings taken approximately 3 hours 40 minutes later at 1:22 PM.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 72°F dropping to 57°F overnight. Clear conditions expected around 6:00 PM.
journal.observations: The plant displays excellent overall health with uniform leaf color, crisp turgor, and no signs of wilt or scorch. Two fully open red blooms are visible with several forming berries swelling evenly beneath the canopy. The crown appears tight and thick, producing symmetrical sets of leaves and buds with no rot, softness, or darkening. Leaf texture is firm with strong venation and no spotting, chlorosis, or edge crisping. Small green fruits show proper drupelet development with no deformities, confirming successful pollination. Soil appears properly leveled and enriched with no compaction visible following the practice of filling probe holes.
journal.actions: Do not water today; moisture at 33 mS/cm combined with cloudy cool conditions provides adequate hydration. No fertilization required; fertility is low but normal during active fruiting stage. No soil adjustments needed; current leveling and probe-hole filling practice continues to work well. Monitor evening temperature drop to 57°F, which is safe and requires no intervention.
journal.next_steps: Water when moisture drops into the mid-20s range or below, likely tomorrow or the following day depending on sun exposure. Consider light fertilization during the next sunny warm day window if fertility continues to decline. Continue monitoring berry development as fruits progress through early sizing stage. Watch for proper fruit set on newly opened blooms over the next several days.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 65°F overnight. Rain expected around 6:00 PM.
journal.observations: The plant shows vigorous new growth with strong upright leaves and several red blossoms fully open. Fruit clusters continue swelling steadily with excellent uniformity. The crown remains properly exposed after soil-level adjustments. Soil appears evenly leveled with no large probe holes or air pockets following the practice of filling holes after probe removal. No signs of pests, rot, discoloration, or stress visible on any foliage. Higher EC and salt readings align with fresh soil added to probe holes and the top layer rather than fertilizer excess.
journal.actions: Do not water today due to expected rain around 6:00 PM. Continue gently filling probe holes with loose potting mix after each reading to prevent soil sinking and air pockets. Maintain canopy exposure and ensure no soil buries the crown during leveling.
journal.next_steps: Next watering expected tomorrow morning unless rain is heavier than forecast. Monitor soil moisture after evening rain to confirm adequate hydration. Continue filling probe holes to maintain stable soil level around the root zone. Watch for any fungal issues following rain, though crown airflow and elevation reduce risk significantly.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether adding soil to probe holes and leveling the soil under the plant was appropriate; confirmed this practice is correct and beneficial as it prevents air pockets from forming around feeder roots. The temporary rise in EC and salt readings is explained by the nutrient-rich fresh soil added and poses no harm to the plant.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight. Thunderstorms forecast around 4:00 PM. Light sun-shower occurred shortly after the reading at 11:16 AM.
journal.observations: The plant displays full, healthy foliage with firm matte-green leaves showing no new spotting or burn. Multiple deep pink and red flower buds are significantly more advanced than yesterday, pushing toward opening. Existing green berries remain firm and well-formed with no signs of shrivel, rot, or physical damage. The canopy is full without overcrowding, and petioles hold leaves at healthy angles with no drooping from heat or overwatering. Soil surface appears slightly chunky and loose with good aeration and no crusting, pooling, slime, or algae. The mix of swelling fruit plus new buds fits perfectly with the early fruiting and active flowering stage.
journal.actions: No watering required today; moisture is comfortable, and expected thunderstorms will provide additional water. Allow storms to top off the pot naturally. Continue full sun exposure under mostly cloudy conditions. No fertilizer or amendments needed; readings remain in healthy ranges.
journal.next_steps: After storms pass, visually check that no standing water or mud has accumulated around the crown. Gently lift leaves to confirm crown is not buried or sitting in a puddle, and check that no petals or debris are stuck in tight wet clusters around new buds. Wait to water manually until moisture dips into mid-30s or below and top 1–1.5 inches of soil feels noticeably lighter and drier by finger test, likely tomorrow or the following day depending on storm intensity. Monitor pH over the next few days to ensure it stays in the mid-5s band as storms leach the pot.

journal.conditions: Sunny all day with a high of 84°F dropping down to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant displays vigorous upright foliage with no signs of heat stress or wilting despite warm afternoon sun. The crown remains completely healthy with new leaf primordia visible and no burial or rot. Multiple berry clusters continue swelling with early reddening visible on one berry, marking the beginning of color progression. The runner is elongating steadily but not yet long enough for rooting. Soil appears loose and well-aerated with even water penetration following afternoon watering. No pests, leaf-edge damage, or fungal spotting visible on any foliage.
journal.actions: No fertilizer applied; EC is low but stable and adequate for active berry swell. Continue full sun exposure. Allow runner to extend further before attempting propagation. Monitor berry color progression as the plant approaches early color stage.
journal.next_steps: Water when moisture drops into the 20–30 mS/cm range. Monitor berry development closely as color change accelerates. Recheck pH within 48 hours to track post-watering stabilization. Continue observing runner length for future propagation timing. Watch for increased color development on berries over the next several days.
follow_up: [2:33 PM] Watered the plant; unable to complete morning watering schedule so watered in afternoon instead.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high near 84°F and an overnight low near 63°F.
journal.observations: The plant displays excellent stabilization with all leaves upright and richly green. The crown area is producing new leaf primordia cleanly with no signs of rot or stress. Several berry clusters are visibly larger than previous days, consistent with active early fruit swell. The soil surface appears loose and well-aerated with no compaction or crusting. The crown remains fully visible above the soil line following yesterday's soil top-up. No pests, leaf-spot, or scorching visible on any foliage. The runner continues elongating but is not yet long enough for rooting.
journal.actions: No watering required; moisture is ideal. No fertilizer applied due to adequate EC and recent pH stabilization. No soil adjustments needed. Continue full sun exposure. Allow runner to extend further before attempting propagation.
journal.next_steps: Monitor soil moisture over the next 24–48 hours and water only if readings drop significantly. Recheck pH with multiple probe locations within 2–3 days to confirm continued stabilization across the entire pot. Continue observing berry growth and size progression as the plant advances through early fruit swell. Watch runner development for future propagation once it extends far enough to reach a separate pot comfortably. Periodically confirm the crown remains visible above soil line as the mix settles.

photos.caption: Side angle view showing healthy foliage and visible developing berry clusters.
Top-down view capturing leaf canopy structure with multiple berries in early fruit swell.
Overhead angle showing upright leaf posture and clean crown area with emerging new growth.
Top view displaying even leaf distribution and berry clusters at various development stages.

journal.conditions: Sunny midday around 84°F with an overnight low expected near 63°F.
journal.observations: The plant displays vigorous vegetative growth with a high leaf count, which is normal and desirable for a young plant actively developing fruit. Leaves are upright, richly green, and well-spaced, indicating strong crown activity and healthy photosynthetic capacity. Several developing berries are visible and continuing to enlarge, consistent with the early fruit swell stage. The crown is clean and fully exposed with no signs of rot or fungal issues. The soil surface appears dry and somewhat low in the pot, with 1–2 inches of headspace before topping up, matching the low moisture reading. The pH has risen significantly compared to prior acidic pockets and now sits at a more stable value, suggesting improved normalization of lime distribution within the mix.
journal.actions: No pruning performed as all leaves are healthy and contributing to fruit production. Water approximately 1/2 to 3/4 cup evenly to rehydrate the root zone. Add a modest amount of fresh organic potting mix to raise the soil level while keeping the crown fully exposed and the soil loose. No fertilizer applied due to adequate growth and low EC. Plant left in full sun under warm conditions.
journal.next_steps: Monitor soil moisture after today's watering to ensure it returns to a moderate range. Recheck pH in the next 24–48 hours using multiple probe locations around the pot to confirm continued stabilization. Continue observing berry growth and leaf posture as the plant progresses through the early fruit swell stage. Watch runner development for future propagation once it extends far enough to comfortably reach a separate pot. Periodically confirm that the crown remains visible above the soil line as the mix settles over time.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the large number of leaves was a concern and confirmed that abundant, healthy foliage is normal and beneficial for supporting berry development. User noted that the pot had 1–2 inches of headspace and asked if more organic potting mix should be added; recommended partially topping up the pot by about 1 inch while keeping the crown fully exposed and the soil loose. After adding soil, user asked for confirmation that the new soil level was appropriate, which was affirmed.
follow_up: [1:10 PM] Added fresh organic potting mix to raise soil level by about 1 inch while keeping the crown fully exposed and the soil loose.

photos.caption: Close-up near the crown showing healthy new leaf growth and developing berry clusters.
Top-down view showing dense but healthy leaf canopy with good spacing and upright posture.
Side angle of Strawberry (Left) showing berry clusters and vigorous foliage.
Additional top-down view capturing full plant shape and leaf distribution.
Before adding soil: pot shows extra headspace around the root zone and a fully exposed crown.
After topping up soil: level is raised evenly while keeping the crown clear and unobstructed.
Side view after adding potting mix confirming the new soil level supports stems without burying the crown.
Final angle showing evenly distributed potting mix and upright, healthy foliage after topping up.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy morning around 84°F with an overnight low expected near 67°F.
journal.observations: The plant shows strong, healthy growth with upright foliage and developing berries. No wilting, yellowing, or leaf-edge damage is visible. Despite the acidic probe value, the plant does not exhibit stress symptoms typically associated with extremely low pH, indicating that today's reading is likely due to localized soil variation rather than whole-pot acidity. Soil structure appears loose and aerated, with a mixture of Miracle-Gro and nursery potting mix visible. Berries continue to swell, and runner extension remains active. Overall plant vigor is consistent with the early fruit swell stage.
journal.actions: No lime applied despite low pH reading due to evidence of pH pocketing rather than generalized acidity. No fertilizer added. Plant continues receiving natural light under mostly cloudy conditions. Light watering planned for later in the day to help even out moisture and salt distribution.
journal.next_steps: Give a small, even watering of approximately 1/3 to 1/2 cup to help normalize moisture, salts, and lime distribution. Recheck pH within 24–48 hours using 2–3 different probe locations. Monitor developing berries for continued sizing and color progression. Continue observing runner length for future propagation.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the second reading told a different story; confirmed that the difference between readings indicated soil heterogeneity rather than true whole-pot acidity. User clarified that the soil had not been fluffed, reinforcing the interpretation that localized pockets caused the low pH reading. No stress response was seen in the plant, supporting this conclusion.

photos.caption: Morning view of Strawberry (Left) showing healthy foliage and berry clusters.
Top-down view of the canopy showing multiple developing berries and even growth.
Side view capturing berry clusters in the early fruit swell stage.
Angle highlighting new leaf growth and runner extension forming from the crown.

journal.conditions: Sunny afternoon around 84°F with an overnight low expected near 60°F.
journal.observations: The plant shows vigorous, healthy growth with upright foliage and multiple developing berries. Leaf color is rich and even, with no new spotting or lesions. Runners are beginning to extend but have not yet reached a length suitable for rooting in a separate pot. Soil moisture is in a well-balanced upper-moderate range, and the pH has reached an ideal strawberry range for the first time. Developing berries appear slightly larger compared to prior days, indicating steady progress through the early fruit swell stage.
journal.actions: No watering performed since moisture was within ideal range. No fertilizer applied to avoid disrupting the newly stabilized pH. Runners were monitored but left attached to continue extending until long enough for propagation.
journal.next_steps: Check soil moisture within 24–36 hours and water only if readings drop to a low or mid range. Continue monitoring runner growth and prepare a small pot for rooting once the runner lengthens. Maintain full sun exposure through the afternoon and allow natural cooling overnight. Keep monitoring berry development as they progress toward sizing and color change.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the long shoots were suckers and if they could be used for propagation; confirmed they are runners, which can root into a pot once longer. User asked if waiting was acceptable and was advised that waiting is ideal until the runner extends further and forms a clearer daughter plantlet.

photos.caption: Side view of Strawberry (Left) showing healthy foliage and visible developing berries.
Top-down view highlighting leaf structure and positioning of developing fruits.
Close-up of berry cluster displaying early fruit swell stage.
Angle showing early runner growth beginning to extend from the crown.

journal.conditions: Sunny late morning around 81°F with a forecast high near 83°F and an overnight low around 62°F.
journal.observations: The plant appears overall healthy with upright, richly green foliage and several developing fruits visible. The soil was extremely dry at the time of the reading, with a moisture value of 0.00 mS/cm and a loose, fibrous surface. No active lesions or pest damage are visible on leaves. Some older flowers have finished and dropped petals, while new buds and small berries are forming.
journal.actions: Water the plant lightly and evenly with a slow pour to rehydrate the root zone without oversaturating the pot. No fertilizer applied due to low pH and low EC. Plant kept in full sun with the option for light afternoon shade if temperatures exceed the low 80s. No pruning required today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture the following morning to confirm it has risen into a moderate range. Apply a very small amount of garden lime once it arrives and the soil is slightly moist to begin raising pH toward the ideal range. Continue to monitor older leaves for any recurring white spotting and remove only if damage worsens. Protect the plant if a cold night below 40°F is forecast.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether a leaf shown in a new photo was the previously spotted one; confirmed it was not and that the damaged leaf was likely removed earlier. Clarified that no leaves in the new image needed pruning. User also asked if the very dry reading meant watering was necessary, and was advised to water with about 1/2 to 3/4 cup total poured slowly around the root zone.
follow_up: [10:57 AM] Watered per instructions; soil now evenly moist and should stabilize pH and support fruit development.
[11:04 AM] Followed watering instructions; soil appears evenly rehydrated with stable moisture distribution.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing dense, healthy foliage and overall plant shape after watering.
Side view of Strawberry (Left) displaying leaf posture and developing fruit clusters.
Close-up of crown area with visible small green berries and new leaf growth.
Soil surface close-up showing previously dry fibrous texture before and after watering.

journal.conditions: Cool, clear morning around 68°F with full sun and light dew on foliage, warming later in the day.
journal.observations: The plant appeared full and vigorous with firm leaves and several active blooms. Dew was present on the foliage and soil surface in the morning. Soil moisture was moderate at 45 mS/cm, suggesting adequate water levels following prior irrigation. One bloom appeared to be drooping naturally at the end of its cycle. No new leaf-spot lesions or pest activity were visible.
journal.actions: No watering performed since moisture was in a comfortable range. No fertilizer or lime added while waiting for pH correction materials to arrive. Plant left in full sun to dry off the morning dew.
journal.next_steps: Monitor soil moisture later in the day if temperatures rise significantly, and water only if the top layer becomes dry and readings drop well below the current level. Plan to apply a small amount of lime once it arrives to begin raising pH. Remove spent blooms or petals as needed to keep the crown tidy and reduce fungal risk.

photos.caption: Morning view of Strawberry (Left) with dew on leaves and upright posture.
Top-down view showing leaf canopy and a mix of blooms and small developing berries.
Side angle highlighting a drooping flower at the end of its cycle.

journal.conditions: Warm, sunny late morning around 79°F with full sun and dry air.
journal.observations: The plant remained upright with healthy new leaves and active blossoms, but the soil was very dry, reflected by the low moisture reading of 13 mS/cm. The surface appeared slightly compacted. One lower leaf showed white spots and brown lesions consistent with minor leaf spot or localized damage. Blossoms were open and some petals were beginning to shed normally.
journal.actions: Water the plant with approximately 1/2 cup of water poured slowly around the root zone to relieve dryness. Remove the single damaged lower leaf with white spotting to improve airflow and reduce the chance of disease spread. Fertilizer withheld and lime application deferred until the product arrives and soil moisture is more stable. Afternoon heat exposure monitored to avoid additional stress.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture within 24 hours to ensure the watering restored levels to a moderate range. Apply a light dusting of lime when soil is moist and lime is available to begin correcting the low pH. Continue monitoring other leaves for new spotting and keep an eye on blossoms and developing berries.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the warmer temperature and dry reading meant the plant needed water and was advised to water with about 1/2 cup. User also asked whether the spotted lower leaf should be removed and was advised to remove it to reduce risk of disease and improve airflow.

photos.caption: Overview of plant showing upright foliage and flowers before watering.
Close-up of the lower leaf with white spots and lesions prior to removal.
Top view of soil surface illustrating dryness and slight compaction.

journal.conditions: Cool clear morning around 61°F with full sun.
journal.observations: The plant was upright, green, and healthy with a vibrant bloom and no new spotting noted. Soil moisture was borderline moderate at 35 mS/cm, indicating it was not yet dry but trending in that direction. Salt and EC levels were low to moderate and within a safe range. Overall the plant appeared to be stabilizing well after transplant.
journal.actions: No immediate watering performed; plan to water only if the top inch of soil feels dry on inspection. Lime application postponed to allow the soil and pH to stabilize naturally. Fertilizer delayed for 5–7 days to avoid stressing the recently transplanted plant. Full sun exposure maintained.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture within 24 hours and water if the top inch is dry. Reassess pH before applying any lime. Evaluate fertility later in the week once the plant has had more time to adjust to the new pot.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the plant needed water given the borderline moisture reading; the response was to water only if the top inch of soil felt dry, as the current reading suggested it was close but not yet critical.

photos.caption: Early view of Strawberry (Left) shortly after transplant, showing a vibrant flower and healthy leaves.
Side view of the new pot and plant structure in full sun.
